item.title: US confirms first-ever 'severe' human bird flu; California declares emergency - NewsBytes
item.description:
California Declares Emergency as US Reports First Severe Human Bird Flu Case

Date: October 2023 | Source: NewsBytes

California Governor Gavin Newsom has declared a state of emergency as bird flu spreads rapidly among dairy cattle. The outbreak has made California the nation's hotspot for cattle infections.

  • Over 300 dairy herds in California have tested positive for bird flu in the last month.
  • The first severe human case of bird flu in the US was reported in Louisiana, with a resident hospitalized after exposure.
  • A total of 61 people have been infected with bird flu in the US, with indications of undercounting.
  • A teenager in British Columbia was hospitalized with the D1.1 strain, but the source of infection remains unclear.
Dr. Demetre Daskalakis stated, "Infections without a clear source of exposure do occur," emphasizing a lack of evidence for human-to-human transmission.

The declaration is a proactive measure to provide government agencies with necessary resources to address the outbreak and its potential health implications.

item.title: Tamil Nadu sought adding mumps vaccine in UIP - The Hindu
item.description:
Tamil Nadu Advocates for Mumps Vaccine Inclusion in Universal Immunisation Programme

Date: December 19, 2024
Source: Tamil Nadu Journal of Public Health and Medical Research

Tamil Nadu has requested the Government of India to include the mumps vaccine in the Universal Immunisation Programme (UIP) in response to a rising number of mumps cases. The move aims to improve public health and control disease spread.

  • Tamil Nadu records approximately 150 to 200 mumps cases monthly.
  • The Directorate of Public Health has advised the inclusion of MMR vaccine in routine immunisation.
  • Current UIP covers 11 vaccines against 12 diseases for children and pregnant women.
  • The cases of mumps have shown a significant increase, especially in 2023-24, with over 1,000 reported cases.
  • The largest percentage of cases occurred in children aged six to nine and less than five years.
  • Experts warn of potential complications in adults and support the policy decision to include mumps in UIP.
“In view of the growing evidence of complications due to shift in the age group, it is advisable to include mumps in the UIP.” - Dr. T. S. Selvavinayagam

The request from Tamil Nadu aims to enhance vaccination efforts for mumps to prevent possible outbreaks and complications, emphasizing the importance of government support for implementation.

item.title: Self-reported walking speed can predict metabolic disease risk - News-Medical.Net
item.description:
Self-reported walking speed can predict metabolic disease risk

Publication Date: November 15, 2024 | Source: Scientific Reports

Walking speed is regarded as a crucial health indicator, often termed the "sixth vital sign." A recent study in Japan revealed that individuals with a self-reported fast walking speed have a significantly lower risk of metabolic diseases, even when dealing with obesity.

  1. The study, led by Prof. Kojiro Ishii, ties subjective walking speed to lower odds of hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia.
  2. Data was collected from 8,578 participants identified as obese, with findings suggesting 30% lower risk of diabetes for faster walkers.
  3. The research emphasizes the potential of using simple self-assessment tools in public health screenings.

"Promoting a faster walking pace may be a helpful individual behavior to help prevent metabolic diseases, particularly in individuals with obesity," notes Dr. Ishii.

The findings suggest that subjective assessments could enhance metabolic disease screenings and provide critical health insights. Future research should be conducted to test these findings longitudinally.

item.title: Russia claims it developed first cancer vaccine in big breakthrough, says 'will distribute for free' - India TV News
item.description:
Russia Claims Breakthrough in Cancer Vaccine Development, Promises Free Distribution

Publication Date: December 19, 2024 | Source: India TV News

Russia has announced the development of a cancer vaccine claimed to prevent all types of tumors, proving successful in pre-clinical trials. The initiative aims to enhance the immune system's ability to combat cancer cells effectively.

  • The vaccine reportedly boosts the immune system to destroy potential cancer cells before they develop.
  • Russian President Vladimir Putin discusses the progress in creating this vaccine and related immunomodulatory drugs.
  • Indian oncologists express caution, noting the vaccine is still in pre-clinical stages and requires further testing.
  • The technology employs mRNA to target cancer cells, triggering the immune response to eliminate them.
  • The vaccine is intended for treatment rather than prevention; conventional preventive vaccines against cancer-causing infections are already available.
"If Russia's claim is linked to reality, then it can prove to be a milestone in the history of cancer," said Dr. Shyam Agarwal, Chairman of the Cancer Department at Sir Ganga Ram Hospital.

As Russia prepares to distribute this vaccine for free, the global medical community awaits more detailed human trial data to understand its efficacy and potential impact on cancer treatment.

item.title: Polio Resurgence In Spain, Germany, and Poland; Virus Detected In Wastewater - TheHealthSite
item.description:
Poliovirus Resurgence In Spain, Germany, and Poland; Nations To Ramp Up Vaccination And Surveillance

Publication Date: Not Specified Source: The Health Site

Three countries in Europe, Germany, Spain, and Poland, have reported the presence of poliovirus in wastewater, raising concerns over a potential resurgence of the disease.

  • Polio Virus Detection Timeline: The VDPV2 was first detected in Spain in mid-September, followed by detections in Poland on November 18 and in multiple cities in Germany throughout November and early December.
  • Public Health Response: The ECDC and WHO are urging countries to maintain high vaccination rates and enhance surveillance to prevent a possible outbreak.
“Although cases have significantly decreased, recent wastewater monitoring serves as a concerning reminder of the ongoing risks.”

Finding the poliovirus in wastewater highlights the need for vigilance in vaccination and public health measures to combat potential outbreaks.

item.title: Can infectious bird flu linger in refrigerated raw milk? Here’s what the study reveals - The Times of India
item.description:
Can infectious bird flu linger in refrigerated raw milk? Here’s what the study reveals

Publication Date: [Insert Date Here] Source: [Insert Source Here]

This article explores the potential for bird flu viruses to survive in refrigerated raw milk, highlighting recent research findings that shed light on this concerning issue.

  • Research indicates that avian influenza can survive in refrigerated conditions.
  • Raw milk may serve as a medium for the transmission of infectious bird flu.
  • Investigation aimed at understanding the implications for food safety and public health.

“Understanding the survival of bird flu in dairy products is crucial for preventing outbreaks.”

The findings underscore the importance of monitoring food products and enhancing safety protocols to prevent potential health risks associated with raw milk consumption.

item.title: The risks of late-night sugar: Weight gain, sleep loss, and more - The Indian Express
item.description:
The Risks of Late-Night Sugar: Weight Gain, Sleep Loss, and More

Publication Date: December 2024   Source: The Indian Express

Consuming sugar late at night can lead to various health issues including weight gain, poor sleep, and metabolic disruptions.

  • Late-night sugar intake causes blood sugar spikes and crashes that disturb sleep quality.
  • The body focuses on glucose metabolism instead of essential recovery processes like hormonal balance.
  • Sugar consumption at night can lower insulin sensitivity, leading to fat storage and weight gain.
  • Increased consumption of sugar at night can raise cortisol levels and decrease melatonin, affecting sleep.
  • Frequent late-night sugar intake can escalate the risk of sleep disorders, including insomnia and sleep apnoea.
  • Sugar can worsen insulin sensitivity in diabetics, increasing risks for serious complications.
  • Late-night sugar consumption is linked with heightened risks of type 2 diabetes and heart disease.
  • Adopting healthier alternatives and mindful eating can help manage late-night cravings.
"Emphasize balanced meals, healthy options like fruit or dark chocolate, and mindful eating to control late-night cravings."

In conclusion, being mindful of sugar consumption at night is vital for maintaining overall health and well-being.

item.title: United States confirms first ‘severe’ case of H5N1 avian flu from backyard poultry - Down To Earth Magazine
item.description:
First Severe Case of H5N1 Avian Flu in the US Linked to Backyard Poultry

Publication Date: December 13, 2023 | Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

A patient from Louisiana has been hospitalized after being diagnosed with a ‘severe’ case of avian influenza A (H5N1), marking the first report of such a case in the United States traced to exposure from backyard poultry.

  • Patient had exposure to sick and dead birds in backyard flocks.
  • Total of 61 human cases of H5N1 reported since April 2023, with most presenting mild symptoms.
  • Wisconsin reported a presumptive positive human case pending CDC confirmation.
  • Viral genome analysis shows the virus belongs to the D1.1 genotype, linked to recent cases in the US and Canada.
  • CDC notes that sporadic cases, while rare, can occur from multiple sources including backyard flocks.
“This case underscores that, in addition to affected commercial poultry and dairy operations, wild birds and backyard flocks also can be a source of exposure,” stated the CDC.

The increase in H5N1 cases emphasizes the need for continued monitoring of avian influenza, particularly in connection to backyard poultry.

item.title: 1st malaria vaccine shows promise against rising cases: Report - Morung Express
item.description:
1st Malaria Vaccine Shows Promise Against Rising Cases: Report

Date: December 19 | Source: IANS

The first blood-stage malaria vaccine RH5.1/Matrix-M shows promise as part of a developing malaria vaccine strategy, according to a recent report.

Key findings from the report include:

  • RH5.1/Matrix-M is safe and highly immunogenic.
  • It is 55% effective against clinical malaria in a delayed third-dose regimen.
  • Over 80% efficacy against severe disease from high levels of malaria parasites.
  • Currently, there are 11 other malaria vaccines in Phase II development.
“This could be a much-needed addition to the currently available malaria vaccines,” said Stephanie Kurdach, Infectious Disease Analyst at GlobalData.

Conclusion: The development of the RH5.1/Matrix-M vaccine may serve as an important tool in malaria prevention, particularly in high-risk regions.

item.title: Mysterious 'Dinga Dinga' virus outbreak in Uganda: It causes uncontrollable shaking - India Today
item.description:
Mysterious 'Dinga Dinga' virus outbreak in Uganda: It causes uncontrollable shaking

Published On: Dec 19, 2024

Source: India Today

A mysterious illness known as 'Dinga Dinga', meaning 'shaking like dancing', has affected around 300 people in Uganda's Bundibugyo district, primarily women and girls. Symptoms include uncontrollable body shaking, fever, and severe weakness, with paralysis occurring in severe cases.

  • Affected individuals experience difficulty in walking due to uncontrollable body tremors.
  • No fatalities have been reported, but health officials stress the importance of early medical attention.
  • Treatment includes antibiotics, with most patients recovering within a week.
  • Health authorities recommend good hygiene practices to prevent spread.
  • Samples have been sent to the Health Ministry for further analysis.
“There is no scientific evidence that herbal medicine can treat this disease. We are using specific treatments, and I urge locals to seek care from district health facilities.” - Dr Kiyita Christopher

In related news, the Democratic Republic of the Congo is also dealing with an unidentified outbreak, with 394 cases and 30 fatalities reported.

item.title: What makes 'khajoor' a winter special? 5 reasons to eat dates in this season - India.com
item.description:
What makes 'khajoor' a winter special? 5 reasons to eat dates in this season

Published Date: Not specified Source: India.com

Khajoor, or dates, are often considered a winter delicacy in many cultures, particularly in regions where they are harvested during the cooler months. Here are five compelling reasons to enjoy dates during this season:

5 Benefits of Dates in Winter

  1. Nutrient-Rich Energy Boost: Dates are packed with essential nutrients, making them an excellent source of energy.
  2. Rich in Antioxidants: Dates are rich in antioxidants that help combat oxidative stress in the body.
  3. Warmth and Comfort: Traditionally used in winter recipes, dates contribute warmth and comfort.
  4. Bone Health: Dates contain minerals essential for maintaining strong bones.
  5. Natural Sweetener for Healthy Treats: Dates serve as a healthier alternative to refined sugars in festive sweets.

Khajoor is not just a delicious winter treat; it offers numerous health benefits that can enhance your seasonal diet.

item.title: TikTok Influencers Driving Raw Milk Sales – But It’s Still A Bad Idea - Men's Health UK
item.description:
TikTok Influencers are Driving Raw Milk Sales – Here’s Why It’s Still a Bad Idea

Publication Date: 2023
Source: Men's Health

With a growing interest in raw milk fueled by influencers on social media, health experts are cautioning against its consumption due to health risks. The trend gains support from public figures but is met with increasing scrutiny from nutritionists.

Key Points

  • Raw milk is trending on social media with claims of health benefits.
  • Sales of raw milk increased by up to 65% in the UK from 2023-2024.
  • Experts warn that raw milk can contain harmful bacteria leading to serious illnesses.
  • Pasteurization is a vital process that significantly reduces health risks.
  • Influencers romanticize natural diets but ignore the historical health issues associated with raw milk.
“I never recommend raw milk.” – Clare Thornton-Wood, Dietitian

In conclusion, while the allure of raw milk is rising, health professionals continue to emphasize the importance of pasteurization and the potential dangers associated with consuming unpasteurized products.

item.title: 10 Ways to Stay Healthy This Winter - Mangalorean.com
item.description:
10 Ways to Stay Healthy This Winter

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: Mangalorean.com

As winter descends and temperatures drop, maintaining our health can become a secondary concern. However, prioritizing our well-being during this season is crucial, as the cold months can affect our physical and mental health. Here are ten effective strategies to help you stay healthy throughout the winter.

  • Nourish Your Body: Focus on a balanced diet rich in whole grains, lean proteins, fruits, and vegetables.
  • Stay Active: Engage in regular physical activities like yoga and brisk walking.
  • Protect Your Skin: Use moisturizers and sunscreen to combat dry skin.
  • Prioritize Sleep: Aim for 7-8 hours of restful sleep each night.
  • Practice Good Hygiene: Wash hands frequently to prevent infections.
  • Regular Health Checkups: Schedule checkups for early detection of health issues.
  • Quit Smoking: Improve lung health by quitting smoking.
  • Vitamin D: Ensure adequate Vitamin D levels through sunlight or supplementation.
  • Dress Warmly: Wear warm clothing to protect from the cold.
  • Stay Connected: Maintain social connections to promote mental well-being.

With these ten strategies, you can enhance your health and well-being during the winter months. Remember, proactive measures are the key to enjoying a vibrant and healthy winter season.

item.title: Beyond supplements: How lifestyle changes can boost immunity - News9 LIVE
item.description:
Beyond supplements: How lifestyle changes can boost immunity

Date: New Delhi

Source: News9Live

In today's world, strengthening the immune system is essential as new health challenges emerge. Strong immunity not only fights infections but also supports a healthy, long life. Simple lifestyle changes can significantly enhance immune function.

  • Proper Nutrition: A balanced diet of fruits, vegetables, nuts, seeds, and legumes provides essential nutrients and antioxidants that combat pathogens.
  • Follow Adequate Hydration: Staying hydrated supports overall health and immune function.
  • Regular Exercise: Moderate exercise boosts mental health and immune function.
  • Prioritize Stress Management: Techniques such as mindfulness, yoga, and meditation can reduce stress and its negative effects on immunity.
  • Practice Good Sleep: Adequate sleep is crucial for the immune system to function effectively.
  • Take Supplements Wisely: Consult with experts before using supplements to ensure they are safe and effective.
“It is possible to state that building up the immune system is not about finding quick fixes and pills; it is about making the right choices that affect the body positively.”

In conclusion, creating a resilient immune system involves consistent lifestyle choices, ensuring that individuals prioritize health through diet, exercise, stress management, and proper sleep.
